title: 106_s1654
content: The "Florida Coast Protection Act of 1999" requires environmental impact statements for exploration, development, or production plans under the Coastal Zone Management Act. States must receive an environmental impact statement before considering necessary data and information. Additionally, the Act establishes uniform documentation requirements. SEC. 3 amends Section 25 of the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act by removing references to the Gulf of Mexico and striking subsection (l). SEC. 4 addresses oil and gas development and production. Section 25(e) of the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act of 1972 is amended to define major federal actions for development and production plans in the Gulf of Mexico as covered areas under the National Environmental Policy Act of 1969. The Environmental Policy Act of 1969 requires the Secretary to provide affected States with the final environmental impact statement at least 180 days before determining concurrence or objection to the coastal zone consistency certification for development and production plans in covered areas. The Secretary must provide affected States with the final environmental impact statement at least 180 days before determining concurrence or objection to coastal zone consistency certification for development and production plans in covered areas. SEC. 5. LEASING ACTIVITY OFF THE COAST OF FLORIDA. Section 8 of the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act is amended to include leasing activity off the coast of Florida in specific planning areas. The Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act is amended to include leasing activity in the South Atlantic Planning Area adjacent to Florida within 100 miles off the coast. Preleasing activity includes scheduling lease sales, requesting industry interest, and issuing calls for proposals. The term 'preleasing activity' includes issuing calls for information or nominations, identifying areas for leasing, publishing environmental impact statements, and conducting rotary drilling. Exclusions are scientific analyses or evaluations. The Secretary is prohibited from conducting preleasing activities or lease sales in covered areas under this Act.
